summary: The U.S. District Court for the Central District of California today entered a final judgment against Bond Safeguard Insurance Company, Inc., a San Diego, California-based insurance company, for failing to provide timely and sufficient notice of completion of a work of improvement.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed on July 25, 2011, in the Southern District of Los Angeles, R&R Pipeline, Inc. ("R&R"), entered into a contract with Los Valles Company, LP ("Los Valles"), for installation of a storm drain, sanitary sewer, and related improvements on land in Castaic, California.  The contract required R&r to complete the work on the project by September 24, 2008, and the contract required completion of the work by October 1, 2008.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, the defendants consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins them from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders them to pay disgorgement of $1,085,858.64 under the contract and an additional $150,000 in restocking charges on materials ordered by the County.  In its judgment, the court also ordered R’s compliance with the reporting provisions of Sections 5(a), 5(c), and 17(a) ofÂ the Securities Act of 1933 ("Securities Act") and Rules 5(b)(5) and 17a-1 thereunder.  R&Rs agreed to settle the case by consenting to a judgment permanently enjoining them from future violations of the federal securities laws, ordering them to disgorge their ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, and ordering R&RS to pay a civil penalty equal to the amount of the bonds it has already paid to the county.  On August 2, 2013, the SEC filed a complaint in the United States District Court in Los Angeles charging R&&R with violations of Section 3100 of the securities laws and with violating Section 15(a)(2) of Exchange Act Rule 15b2-1, and Rule 15a-3 thereunder; and with aiding and abetting violations of Sections 206(1), 206(2) and 206(4)-3 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 ("Advisers Advisers") and Rule 206(3)-8 thereunder and with respect to liability under Section 15A of the Exchange Act for the purpose of recovering the bonds.
